HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 5, 1924

STUDENTS PAY ONETHIRD AT HOPKINS
Only one-third of the approximate unit cost per student in the "Collegiate and
Philosophical Departments"
of the Johns Hopkins University, is paid in the average tuition fee of the undergraduate. The otner twothirds of the annual cost of
the average student's education falls on the University,
according to figures released by the Half-Century
Committee in their Handbook. The approximate cost
per student per year is $625,
of which sum the $200 tuition fee represents less than
a third.

TRYOUTS TOMORROW
FOR BARNSTORMERS
Tomorrow evening will
be the annual "Tryout
Night" of the Barnstormers
Club. Five one-act playlets
will he produced by aspirants for the cast of the
Club's main production.
Candidates will have charge
of all ends of the production,
which will be in the Homewood Playshop. Mr. Walter
B. Swindell, Barnstormer
Coach, members of the fac'ulty, Barnstormers, and
Playshoppers will constitute the audience. The first
play is scheduled for 7.30.

Fifteen letters and five "Haa's"
Were voted to members of the
football -squad by the Athletic
Board Monday, December 1. The
letter men are Captain Thomas P.
Magill, Ben Slowik, Edward Milonausky, Karl -Levy, Edward
Day, Douglas C. Turnbull, J.
Walker Taylor, RObert F. Sauerwein, Carroll Berndt, Joseph
Blandi, Wallace Oles, J. Gardner
Mallonee, Carroll Leibensperger,
Willard Almy, Jack Lawrence and
Manager John Parsons. Those
who won the minor award are
Thomas Biddison, Roger Conant,
Jack Gilliece, Alan Gump and
.N
- -elson Young.
Of these, Captain Magill is the
°n1Y one who has seen four years
of continuous service. Turnbull
and Taylor have each won their
letters three times while Slowik,
Berndt and Day have completed
their second year as varsity men.
The remainder of the group won
their insignia for the first time
this year. As the only letter men
to graduate are Magill, Slowik and
Turnbull, and the only Haa man,
Gump, sixteen veterans .will form
the nucleus el nex. year's squad.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 5, 1924

STUDENTS PAY ONETHIRD AT HOPKINS
Only one-third of the approximate unit cost per student in the "Collegiate and
Philosophical Departments"
of the Johns Hopkins University, is paid in the average tuition fee of the undergraduate. The otner twothirds of the annual cost of
the average student's education falls on the University,
according to figures released by the Half-Century
Committee in their Handbook. The approximate cost
per student per year is $625,
of which sum the $200 tuition fee represents less than
a third.

Coach, members of the fac'ulty, Barnstormers, and
Playshoppers will constitute the audience. The first
play is scheduled for 7.30.
